This auction is for a Epiphone Riviera Made In Japan Tan Label 80-84 Matsumoku Plays & Sounds Good. Most of Matsumoku made Epiphone guitars including this guitar don't have serial numbers nor the stamps of "Made in Japan", so you need to identify them by the characters as follows (however this one has a serial number on the headstock). The easiest way to do this is to check the labels within the sound holes. Rivieras produced in the 70s have blue labels, on the other hand those that produced in the 80s have tan/light brown. Matsumoku went bankrupt in the mid 80s. Until then, they have produced a lot of guitars for Greco, Epiphone, etc., but mainly for Aria. "Aria" brand is the property of Arai Boeki (Boeki = trading company). Arai Boeki was also an exclusive distributor for Gibson in the era and had a subsidiary company "Nihon (= Nippon = Japan) Gibson" to sell both Gibson and Epiphone guitars in Japan. All Epiphone guitars made in the era were manufactured in the Matsumoku factory until 1983 or 1984, when the collaboration between Arai and Boeki Gibson has ended. That was only a few years before Matsumoku went bankrupt in 1986. All guitars made in Matsumoku factory which have a set neck joint have some features such as,, 1, there is a screw in the end of the neck. The way of the joint is sometimes called "Matsumoku bolt neck Tennon". 2, three pieces neck The body binding is cracked, chipped away and is coming off as you can see in the pictures but that just adds to the cool vibe. (Even when I took the pictures, some parts of the binding have been chipped away as you can see the pictures in the slideshow. Please note that some more should be coming off when the guitar is wrapped or during the transportation.) The last two digits of the serial number in the pictures is hidden for the sake of the next owner. Condition of the guitar: Almost all of the guitars in my store are not a brand new, but a used one, so they are not always be in "PERFECT" condition. This can be especially true of "VINTAGE" guitars that have had many years of use and because of this they can sometimes have issues with playability, so for many reasons they may need care and maintenance before reaching an optimal playing condition. Please read the following detailed information that should always be considered when buying a used guitar. *NeckNowadays a lot of guitar players know the term "JV" (Japan Vintage) and that the values of guitars made in and around the JV era are getting higher. I am glad and proud as a Japanese person that these guitars were made by expert craftsmen with selected materials and I totally agree with the reputation that these guitars have earned. However, in Japan, there is a significant humidity difference through the year which can have a bad influence on the materials in guitars if they are not well kept & carefully maintained. Additionally these guitars were often purchased by beginners or students and can tend to be poorly treated without ever having any maintenance. Sometimes they are stored away for ages after a very short period of use, as a result it is often the case that they have issue's about the neck. I have played guitar for many years and all the guitars in my store were listed only after I checked & played them personally. All of the guitars in my store passed the normal standards/my standards unless particularly stated otherwise.
